subsc: Primary education,Secondary education,Tertiary education,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
This project is rated unsatisfactory
            overall based on ratings in each of the three project
            objectives. The overall impact of the project on the
            education sector has been negligible. Given the extended
            time period and a high cost of the project, the results are
            judged to be less than satisfactory. Key lessons learned are
            summarized as: The central offices of the Ministry needs to
            build capacity to supervise construction effectively.
            Additional suitably qualified personnel and transport are
            required. Large packages also exclude small local
            contractors, and when a contractor with a large package
            performs poorly, many schools are affected. Thus, smaller
            packages of four to five schools awarded on a geographical
            basis would be more effective and give local contractors an
            opportunity to compete. If effective procedures are
            introduced to enable payments to be made at regional and
            zonal levels, less time will be needed and therefore cost
            savings will be realized. Much time was lost over
            disagreements and misunderstandings about procedures;
            training courses may be necessary for regional staff to
            facilitate the award of contracts at the regional level.
            Insufficient coordination of inputs resulted in poor use of
            resources. More attention needs to be paid to the
            programming and timing of activities related to civil works.
            The cost-effectiveness of providing fencing, electrical
            installations, and plumbing has to be evaluated before civil
            works contracts are awarded.
